content.description: The crux pulling through the overhanging crack.  There is a large flake in the center of the climb that vibrates when you hit it.  It looks like it takes plenty of gear but I wouldn't put anything in it.  Fun & protects reasonably well.  Make sure you have some long slings for an anchor at the top.
content.protection: Standard Rack.  1 rusted fixed pin under the overhang (back it up).
content.location: Looking up from the steep trail - this route is on the wall to your right.  It is the red line in the left of the picture.  You can lead up and walk off the backside of the cliff.

content.description: There a couple exciting moves on this climb.  Climb straight through the overhanging blocks.  The crux is moving past the first block.
content.protection: Build your own anchor at the top.  Make sure you have some long slings.
content.location: Looking up from the steep trail - this route is on the wall to your right. It is the red line in the right of the picture. You can walk around the cliff face to the top and build a gear anchor.

content.description: This is a standard chimney climb.  It has the usual dirt.  Just because the gear fits doesn't mean its good.  Check the quality of the rock.
content.protection: Standard rack.  Use a tree at the top & some long webbing or a static line.
content.location: Looking up from the steep trail - this route is on the wall to your left. It is the red line in the center of the picture. You can lead up and walk off the backside of the cliff.

content.description:
Fun but not terribly often ventured to moderate trad and top rope spot. Its got world class views and a nice, just long enough to warm up approach. Very old and solide stone. Mostly less than vertical but some vertical and some slightly overhanging routes exist.  

  Great place to take the family or climb and connect with the Appalachian Trail.  

  15-20 +/- established climbs. Most, if not all, are 5.8 difficulty and under.
